author: By Benjamin Oreskes
title: N.Y. Families Could Receive Tax Credit of Up to $1,000 Under Hochul Plan
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul has now released two early proposals from her State of the State message that aim to address concerns over the high cost of living.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York on Monday proposed an expansion of the state’s child tax credit that would more than double what some families currently receive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Azerbaijani Anger Over Plane Crash Grows, in Deepening Schism With Russia
description: In the crash’s aftermath, Azerbaijan has unleashed rare and stinging criticism of Russia, with the country’s president saying Moscow’s response has caused “surprise, regret and rightful indignation.”
content: President Ilham Aliyev of Azerbaijan on Monday excoriated Russia for trying to duck responsibility in the downing of an Azerbaijani passenger jet last month, doubling down on a rare confrontation with the Kremlin that has highlighted Russia’s loss of influence in much of the former Soviet Union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: U.S. Sends 11 Guantánamo Prisoners to Oman to Start New Lives
description: The secret mission left the smallest number of prisoners at Guantánamo Bay since the day the detention center opened in 2002.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Russia Claims Control of Key Town as Ukraine Renews Push in Kursk
description: Ukraine has largely been driven out of Kurakhove, a battered but strategic town in the Donbas, Russia said. Kyiv’s forces were pressing a renewed offensive in southern Russia.
content: Five months after storming across the border into the Kursk region of southern Russia, Ukrainian forces were making a renewed push on Monday to drive deeper into Russia, even as they appear to have lost a strategic town in eastern Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Brian Otieno
title: In Africa, Danger Slithers Through Homes and Fields
description: Venomous snakes bite millions of people worldwide each year, killing at least 120,000. Many of them are poor people in rural areas of Africa without easy access to treatment.
content: The snake struck 11-year-old Beatrice Ndanu Munyoki as she sat on a small stone, which lay atop a larger one, watching the family’s eight goats. She was idly running her fingers through the dirt when she saw a red head dart from between the stones and felt a sharp sting on her right index finger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: The Next Chapter in the Amazon-Trump Reset
description: The tech company’s deal to release a film on Melania Trump has renewed scrutiny of Jeff Bezos’s efforts to get closer to the president-elect.
content: Jeff Bezos surprised many when he spoke of his hopes for President-elect Donald Trump’s return to power at the DealBook Summit last month. The duo’s reset took a new twist with Amazon’s announcement that it would release a documentary on Melania Trump shot by an outcast filmmaker, and more tumult at The Washington Post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: ‘The Brutalist’ Wins Best Drama in a Tight Race
description: The film, starring Adrien Brody as a Holocaust survivor and architect, took home the top drama prize.
content: “The Brutalist,” the epic starring Adrien Brody as a Holocaust survivor and architect, took home the top drama prize at the Golden Globes on Sunday, triumphing in a field that included the journalism ethics thriller “September 5” and the Bob Dylan biopic “A Complete Unknown.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Golden Globes Takeaways: ‘Emilia Pérez’ and ‘The Brutalist’ Win Big
description: “Shogun,” the FX drama, also had a strong night, winning best TV drama, best actor, best actress and best supporting actor.
content: Golden Globe voters did little to clear up a blurry awards picture in Hollywood on Sunday, giving little-seen films like “The Brutalist” and “Emilia Pérez” roughly equal treatment and snubbing some perceived Oscar front-runners, including “Anora.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Four Years After Capitol Riot, Congress Certifies Trump’s Victory Peacefully
description: Vice President Kamala D. Harris presided over the certification of her own loss without disputing it, and Democrats made no move to challenge the results.
content: A joint session of Congress on Monday certified President-elect Donald J. Trump’s victory in the 2024 election, peacefully performing a basic ritual of democracy that was brutally disrupted four years ago by a violent pro-Trump mob inflamed by his lie about a stolen election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Mike Rinder, Scientology Spokesman Turned Critic, Dies at 69
description: In a memoir and as a host of the documentary series “Leah Remini: Scientology and the Aftermath,” he accused the church of fostering a culture of abuse.
content: Mike Rinder, a former spokesman for the Church of Scientology who became one of its fiercest critics and who gained prominence as a host of the Emmy Award-winning television series “Leah Remini: Scientology and the Aftermath,” died on Sunday in Palm Harbor, Fla. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and Abu Bakr Bashir
title: Hamas Approves List of Hostages It May Free Under a Cease-Fire Deal With Israel
description: Israel says Hamas has not provided any information about the status of those 34 hostages, dampening any notion that the endorsement is a step toward a deal to stop the war.
content: As Israeli and Hamas officials continued indirect talks on Monday for a cease-fire and hostage release deal, Hamas representatives indicated that the group had approved an Israeli list of 34 hostages to be released in the first stage of an agreement, conveying a sense of momentum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: West Bank Settlers Hope Trump Will Back Annexation Dreams
description: Settler leaders say they are confident that a Palestinian state is off the table, but their expectations are tempered by their experience of Donald Trump’s first term.
content: Eliana Passentin delights in her house, which sits nearly 3,000 feet above sea level in a Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank, with a view from the Jordan River to the Mediterranean coast. The dining room looks out over ancient Shiloh, the Israelites’ first capital in ancient times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner and Justin Porter
title: Tuesday Briefing: Canada’s Prime Minister Is Stepping Down
description: Plus, a recap of the Golden Globes.
content: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada said yesterday that he would step down as Liberal Party leader and prime minister. The decision by Trudeau, who has led the country for nearly a decade, means that new leadership will take over in Canada by late March after his party picks a new head. Here’s the latest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: Sure, the Romans Were Smart. But They Could Have Been Smarter.
description: Exposure to lead from mining probably lowered I.Q. levels in the empire, research has found. It might be the world’s first case of widespread industrial pollution.
content: Roughly 2,000 years ago, the Roman Empire was flourishing. But something sinister was in the air. Literally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Pang
title: The Simple Trick to Silky, Juicy Chicken Breast
description: Velveting, a Chinese culinary technique, makes lean meat tender. Here, it’s adapted for home-cooked meals any night of the week.
content: The chicken pieces in the chef Elmo Han’s kung pao are so remarkably tender that when teeth meet meat, the poultry barely offers a fight. The dish he serves at Shanghai Terrace, a fine dining restaurant in the Peninsula Chicago Hotel, is a faithful interpretation of the classic, but noteworthy in that it includes chicken breast instead of thighs. White meat, in less capable hands, can quickly dry out and toughen into shoe leather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Nikki Glaser Delivers a Globes Monologue That Involved Some Revising
description: The host had been working on the jokes as well as the flow in multiple test runs in clubs. On the telecast, she introduced some new bits.
content: When I started following Nikki Glaser in early December as she began putting together her Golden Globes monologue, she planned a joke that never made it into Sunday’s awards show about shouting out Harrison Ford and then saying, “Harrison Ford is here to show us a cool rock he found.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: On the Run, a Hit Man Gives a Final Confession
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 6, 2025.
content: “For almost 24 years, I killed and disposed of many bodies. I am trying to remember, but I cannot remember everyone.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Demi Moore Caps Her Comeback With a Win at the Globes
description: She received the award for best actress in a musical or comedy for her performance in the body horror film “The Substance.”
content: Demi Moore won the Golden Globe for best actress in a musical or comedy on Sunday for playing a fading star who goes to extreme lengths to regain her youth in the body horror film “The Substance.” The role has been viewed as a major comeback for the actress, who was best known for her work in the 1980s and ’90s and who was last nominated in the same category in 1991 for “Ghost.” (In classic Globes fashion, it’s debatable whether either “Ghost” or “The Substance” belongs in the comedy race.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Courts in ‘State of Disarray’ on Law Disarming Felons
description: The Supreme Court has repeatedly ducked Second Amendment challenges to the law. Starkly differing decisions from federal appeals courts last month may change that.
content: A federal law makes it a crime for lots of people to have guns. It is, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. wrote in 2019, “no minor provision.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: U.S. Envoy Says Israel Will Withdraw From Southern Lebanon
description: With the deadline looming for the terms of a fragile cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah to be met, an American diplomat on Monday said “much progress” had been made recently.
content: A top U.S. envoy who helped broker the cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah issued reassurance on Monday that Israel would withdraw fully from southern Lebanon, as called for in the fragile 60-day truce deal that paused the bloodiest war between the two sides in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Bromley
title: Do Our Dogs Have Something to Tell the World?
description: Many owners think so, thanks to the “talking buttons” craze on TikTok and Instagram. Scientists are less convinced.
content: As soon as I got Ellie, my black-eyed, bat-eared German shepherd puppy, I trained her to be a good dog. And so she was. When I spoke, she listened; she kept her barks quiet and her teeth clean. Two years on, I started to think she was a little too obedient. There was something pitiful about the way that, even unleashed in the park, she would stop at a fork in the path and look to me to point the way. In the house, she would pause behind a half-closed door instead of pushing through. She was hesitant, whining when she was unsure of herself, in a way that clashed with her big muscles and pointy canines. One day, when the cat in our local bodega poked its head out of the store, Ellie squealed like a child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino and Elise Blanchard
title: Emeralds for Sale: The Taliban Look Below Ground to Revive the Economy
description: The Taliban government is counting on Afghanistan’s bountiful gemstone and mineral resources after the loss of billions of dollars in international aid.
content: In a chilly auditorium in Afghanistan, heaps of freshly mined green emeralds glowed under bright table lamps as bearded gemstone dealers inspected them for purity and quality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Alan Feuer, Robert Jimison, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Harris to Certify Trump’s Victory, and Driving in Manhattan Gets Pricier
description: Plus, you probably haven’t seen the Golden Globe winners.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Ian Austen, Vjosa Isai and Thomas Fuller
title: Trudeau to Resign as Canada’s Prime Minister: ‘It’s Time for a Reset’
description: Justin Trudeau announced Monday that he was also stepping down as leader of Canada’s Liberal Party. He will remain in both roles until a replacement is chosen.
content: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada said on Monday that he would step down in the coming months, bowing to an angry electorate at a time of uncertain economic prospects and political infighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: U.K.’s Starmer Slams ‘Lies and Misinformation’ After Elon Musk Attacks
description: Without naming Mr. Musk directly, Prime Minister Keir Starmer denounced the billionaire’s spreading of falsehoods about a child sex abuse scandal.
content: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain on Monday fired back at Elon Musk after days of inflammatory social media posts by Mr. Musk, the billionaire owner of X, indirectly accusing him and others of “spreading lies and misinformation” about victims of child sex abuse gangs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Journalists at The Athletic Move to Join New York Times Union
description: The NewsGuild of New York asked The Times to voluntarily recognize journalists from the sports news website as part of the newsroom’s union.
content: Journalists at The Athletic, a sports news website owned by The New York Times, intend to unionize, they said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley and Winnie Hu
title: New York’s Congestion Pricing Plan Just Started, but Could Be Undone
description: The program is the target of several lawsuits and of President-elect Donald J. Trump, who said he will end it permanently once he takes office on Jan. 20.
content: After decades of delays and many hard-fought attempts to stop it, New York City’s congestion pricing program has finally begun.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Jan. 6, 2025
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 6, 2025.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Historians’ Group Votes to Condemn ‘Scholasticide’ in Gaza
description: After contentious debate, members of the American Historical Association voted to condemn what a resolution described as Israel’s destruction of Gaza’s educational system.
content: Members of the American Historical Association, the country’s largest group of professional historians, approved a resolution on Sunday evening condemning Israel’s military action in Gaza. It argued that the destruction of most of the enclave’s education infrastructure, along with many archives and libraries, amounted to “scholasticide.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: ‘Forever Chemicals’ Reach Tap Water via Treated Sewage, Study Finds
description: Wastewater, even after treatment to make it drinkable, contains high levels of PFAS, according to researchers.
content: As the world grapples with climate change, population growth and dwindling supplies of fresh water, more people are set to rely on treated wastewater to sustain their daily lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Ex-Prosecutor Ordered Disbarred After Framing Colleague for Sexual Harassment
description: The woman created fake text messages and changed her phone records to falsely implicate a male investigator in the Denver District Attorney’s Office, a judicial office ruled.
content: A prosecutor in the Denver District Attorney’s Office, who was fired two years ago, has been ordered disbarred after framing a male colleague for sexual harassment, a Colorado judicial office ruled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: The Jan. 6 Rioters, 4 Years Later
description: Hundreds of rioters accused of nonviolent crimes during the attack on the Capitol have wrapped up their cases. Here’s what some of their lives look like now.
content: In the past four years, nearly 1,600 people have been prosecuted in connection with the storming of the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Some were accused of felonies like assault or seditious conspiracy and are still in prison. But hundreds charged with lesser crimes have wrapped up their cases and returned to their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Paxlovid Improved Long Covid Symptoms in Some Patients, Researchers Report
description: But the report, on the experiences of 13 patients, found that the drug had no benefit for some people and that some who benefited said the improvement didn’t last.
content: Can Paxlovid treat long Covid? A new report suggests it might help some patients, but which patients might benefit remains unclear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: A Brooklyn Arts Group Gets Its Own Home, a Place to Defy Gravity
description: 651 Arts, dedicated to African diasporic performance, now has its own space to support work like the choreographer André Zachery’s “Against Gravity.”
content: Toya Lillard is not a real estate agent. But she had the practiced patter of one, a few weeks ago, while giving a tour of the new headquarters of 651 Arts, a Brooklyn organization dedicated to African diasporic performance. For an arts administrator, she’s been giving a lot of tours lately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Alter
title: Who Owns Jan. 6?
description: Trump is trying to rewrite history, but history may not comply.
content: The Dutch historian Pieter Geyl said, “History is an argument without end.” Not always. Many big historical questions are firmly settled. No one seriously suggests that the Watergate break-in was justified, and even Marjorie Taylor Greene retracted her claim that Sept. 11 was an inside job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: The Vivienne, Winner of RuPaul’s Drag Race UK, Dies at 32
description: James Lee Williams was best known by that stage name and also built a career in musical theater.
content: James Lee Williams, a drag performer and winner of the inaugural season of “RuPaul’s Drag Race UK” who was best known by the stage name The Vivienne, died over the weekend. They were 32.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anderson Tepper
title: Anita Desai Has Put Down Roots, but Her Work Ranges Widely
description: Her new novella, “Rosarita,” takes place in Mexico, a country she finds so like her native India that, she says, “I feel utterly at home there.”
content: Anita Desai has lived in Delhi and London and Boston, but when she settled, she chose the Hudson River Valley, in New York State. She first came 40 years ago, to visit the filmmakers Ismail Merchant and James Ivory, and was so impressed that she later made her home here, on one of the most dramatic stretches of the river.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Friedrich St. Florian, Architect of World War II Memorial, Dies at 91
description: His design was criticized as banal and beneath its subject. It was also praised for fitting seamlessly into hallowed space on the National Mall.
content: Friedrich St. Florian, an architect whose design for the World War II Memorial on the National Mall in Washington inspired criticism and controversy as well as praise, died on Dec. 18 at his home in Providence, R.I. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Why Is Ariana Grande a Supporting Nominee When Her ‘Wicked’ Role Is a Lead?
description: The pop star plays Glinda in the film, while Cynthia Erivo, who plays Elphaba, is nominated as the lead.
content: As we heard over and over — and over! — during the press tour for “Wicked,” Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande were equally important to the movie. Twinsies. (Turn on the tears here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gerald Narciso
title: Karl-Anthony Towns’s New York City
description: The New York Knicks center-forward and N.B.A. All-Star shares the places that excite him when he’s not on the hardwood at Madison Square Garden.
content: The birth certificate may read New Jersey, but the origin story of Karl-Anthony Towns, the seven-foot star for the New York Knicks, extends to New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Congress Overhauled the Electoral Count Process After the 2021 Violence
description: Bipartisan legislation enacted in 2022 makes it much more difficult for lawmakers to object to a state’s votes, and clarifies that the vice president cannot unilaterally overrule them.
content: Memories of the chaos and violence that disrupted the electoral count in Congress four years ago are still fresh for many on Capitol Hill, but a new law enacted in 2022 has overhauled the process to make it much more difficult to upend the certification.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman and Derek Arthur
title: Trump’s Attack on D.E.I. Will Cost Us All
description: Biden’s cabinet looked like America, and it made the country more successful.
content: In two weeks, the Biden administration will step down, and with it, the most diverse cabinet in American history. In this episode, The Times’s editorial board member Farah Stockman explores the impacts of Joe Biden’s historically significant appointments, both in the United States and abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Win Friends and Influence People
description: How do people get to be No. 1?
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 576
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Jan. 7, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,298
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Jan. 7, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Alan Feuer, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Mooj Zadie, Nina Feldman, Eric Krupke, Mary Wilson, Michael Benoist, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Sophia Lanman, Alyssa Moxley and Carole Sabouraud
title: The Reinvention of Jan. 6
description: Donald Trump and his allies have spent four years trying to change the narrative around the Capitol attack.
content: Since the riot on Capitol Hill four years ago, President-elect Donald Trump and his allies have set out to sanitize the events of that day, changing it from a day of violence into, in Mr. Trump’s words, a day of love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley, Winnie Hu and Nate Schweber
title: N.Y.C. Drivers Face a New Weekday Reality as Congestion Pricing Kicks In
description: The first Monday commute under New York City’s new tolling plan went smoothly, but officials are still assessing how the program is affecting traffic patterns.
content: New York City’s long-awaited congestion pricing plan got off to a smooth start as drivers adjusted to the new tolls, but many crucial questions remained about the nation’s most ambitious traffic experiment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Adrien Brody Wins His First Golden Globe, for ‘The Brutalist’
description: In his speech, the actor said he thought his moment for such honors might have passed.
content: Adrien Brody’s performance as a Hungarian architect in “The Brutalist” has won him his first Golden Globe. In the three-and-a-half hour film directed by Brady Corbet, the actor plays László Tóth, a Holocaust survivor trying to rebuild his life in America following the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Sebastian Stan Wins His First Golden Globe, for ‘A Different Man’
description: The star won best actor in a comedy. He had also been nominated for playing Donald J. Trump in “The Apprentice” but lost to Adrien Brody.
content: Playing an actor with a facial disfigurement who gets an experimental treatment that transforms his appearance but doesn’t help his career has won Sebastian Stan his first Golden Globe, for “A Different Man.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chantal Anderson
title: This Is What It Looks Like to Win a Golden Globe
description: Demi Moore, Adrien Brody, Zoe Saldaña and the stars of “Shogun” and “Baby Reindeer” enjoy their moments of glory.
content: The Los Angeles-based photographer Chantal Anderson was backstage at the Beverly Hilton Hotel on Sunday, where she photographed Golden Globes winners for The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: For Harris, an Awkward Election Task: Certifying the Vote She Lost
description: The vice president presided over Congress on Monday as it counted the Electoral College votes finalizing her defeat by Donald J. Trump.
content: The vice presidency comes with plenty of indignities, but probably none greater than the one that Kamala Harris endured on Monday when she presided over the certification of her own defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Dana White, the Ultimate Fighting Championship C.E.O., Joins Meta’s Board
description: Mr. White, a close ally of President-elect Donald J. Trump, further strengthens the social media giant’s connections with the incoming administration.
content: Mark Zuckerberg said in a Facebook post Monday that Meta had added Dana White, the chief executive of Ultimate Fighting Championship, and two other executives to its board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: In Canada, Covering the Trudeau News With an ‘Orchestra’
description: Times reporters in Toronto, Ottawa and Montreal anticipated that Justin Trudeau would step down as prime minister. Still, covering the news required teamwork, fast thinking and confident execution.
content: On Monday, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada announced that he would resign as Liberal Party leader and prime minister of a country on the cusp of economic upheaval: President-elect Donald J. Trump has pledged to impose tariffs on all United States imports from Canada on his first day in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Michael Gold and Devlin Barrett
title: Trump Says He’ll Replace Leader of National Archives
description: The president-elect’s suggestion that he plans to replace the head of the agency comes after her predecessor raised alarms about his handling of presidential records.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Monday that he plans to replace the head of the National Archives, the agency whose leaders’ concerns about Mr. Trump’s decision to hang on to boxes of documents after he left office ultimately led to a federal indictment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Who’s Afraid of a Flying Dior Bag?
description: To weigh in on the rash of reported drone sightings without fear of content suppression, Bethenny Frankel borrowed a term from the fashion world.
content: In the last few weeks, Bethenny Frankel has been talking a lot about Dior bags on TikTok. The subject itself isn’t unusual: As a reality TV star and entrepreneur, she frequently posts about fashion topics to her 2.4 million followers, including in a feature Ms. Frankel calls “Handbag University,” where she offers reviews and tutorials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Choe Sang-Hun
title: In South Korea, Blinken Affirms Alliance Amid Challenges Facing Democracies
description: The U.S. secretary of state aimed to show that his country stood by South Korea as it grapples with a political crisis, and as Donald J. Trump returns to power.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and the foreign minister of South Korea, Cho Tae-yul, both acknowledged the challenges to democracy in their nations on Monday while asserting that the alliance between the countries remained strong despite ongoing political turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shayla Colon
title: The Mystery of a Subway Victim’s Downward Spiral
description: Debbie Kawam was a high-spirited, happy girl, childhood friends recalled. Then her life took a grim turn.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll read about the early life and downward spiral of Debrina Kawam, the woman who was burned alive on a train in Brooklyn last month at age 57.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Amazon Prime Will Release a Melania Trump Documentary
description: The film, billed by the company as a “behind the scenes” look at her life, started shooting in December and is slated for theatrical and streaming release this year.
content: Amazon said on Sunday that its Prime Video streaming service would release a “behind the scenes” documentary about Melania Trump’s life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague and Euan Ward
title: U.S. Eases Some Restrictions on Humanitarian Aid to Syria
description: The authorization comes after rebels toppled the Syrian government last month and is intended to allow humanitarian groups to operate more freely without running afoul of U.S. sanctions.
content: The Biden administration on Monday lifted some restrictions on humanitarian aid to Syria but kept sweeping sanctions in place just weeks after rebel forces toppled the Assad family’s 50-year authoritarian grip on the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Congress Certified Trump’s Victory Without Disruption
description: Also, Trudeau said he would resign as Canada’s prime minister. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: At a joint session of Congress this afternoon, lawmakers certified President-elect Donald Trump’s victory in the 2024 election. The process was peaceful, quick and uneventful. It stood in stark contrast to this day four years ago, when the basic ritual of democracy was disrupted by a violent pro-Trump mob seeking to overturn the results of the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Worst Golden Globes Fashion Trend
description: Enough with the retro throwback nostalgia — Hollywood needs to be less conservative on the red carpet.
content: Hollywood may be a famously liberal town, but it is starting to look increasingly conservative. Or so it seemed at the Golden Globes, the first official red carpet and communal fashion pageant of the year — and thus theoretically the pacesetter for 2025, or at least the 2025 award season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Anchovies, Always
description: They go full stealth mode in my garlicky chicken with lemon-anchovy sauce, melting quietly into the pan sauce and enhancing the lemon and capers.
content: My unofficial plan for 2025 is to catch up with some of my B.I.F.s (Best Ingredients Forever), and I’ll bet you can guess what’s at the top of the list. That’s right, anchovies! (Don’t worry, dear chocolate; we’ll touch base again around Valentine’s Day.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Diabetes and Heart Disease Rise Alongside Sugary Drink Consumption
description: A new study assesses the effects of sugar-laden beverages on global health, with higher rates of consumption found in Latin America and parts of Africa.
content: Across the world, the consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages is responsible for about 340,000 deaths each year from Type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease, according to a study published Monday that is one of the largest attempts to assess how the spread of Western eating habits is affecting global health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: 19 Unforgettable Looks at the Golden Globes
description: For reasons good and bad, these ensembles were among the most memorable.
content: It wasn’t long after celebrities started arriving on the red carpet at the 82nd annual Golden Globe Awards on Sunday that one of the night’s biggest fashion trends came into focus: metallics. Those who wore them included Zendaya, who went with a coppery orange Louis Vuitton gown; Angelina Jolie, who chose a silvery Alexander McQueen dress; and Cate Blanchett, who donned a gold ensemble, also by Vuitton, that she had previously worn at Cannes and that made her shimmer like a statuette.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen G. Flynn, Raymond S. Park, Pete G. Kovatsis and Anupam B. Jena
title: The Hack That Doctors Should Take From Pop Stars and Quarterbacks
description: Doctors need to warm up too.
content: Imagine a pro quarterback stepping onto the field without his coach running pregame drills or a pop star taking the stage without vocal warm-ups. In sports and music, such last-minute preparation is generally nonnegotiable. Coaches review and refine performance, address weaknesses and ensure readiness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: New York Crime Rate Falls, but Number of Felony Assaults Rises Again
description: Killings and shootings have dropped, but headlines have been dominated by terrifying crimes, like the killing of a woman who was burned to death on the F train.
content: The number of felony assaults and rapes in New York City rose last year even as the overall crime rate fell, Jessica Tisch, the police commissioner, said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: Golden Globes Winners 2025: The Full List
description: The winning films, TV shows, actors and production teams at the 2025 Golden Globe Awards.
content: The first awards show of the season has officially wrapped up after stars collected their trophies, sipped on Moët champagne and snacked on Nobu sushi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: A Ballerina Prized for Her Musicality Deals With Hearing Loss
description: Sara Mearns, the New York City Ballet principal, announced her 10-year struggle on Instagram. She tested out her new hearing aids in “The Nutcracker.”
content: Sara Mearns stepped onto the stage as the Sugarplum Fairy wearing something more precious than a jewel-encrusted tiara. In her ears, invisible to all, were hearing aids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: Pope Names Vocal Supporter of Migrants as Next Cardinal in Washington
description: The appointment of Robert W. McElroy is a signal of the pope’s priorities, two weeks before Donald J. Trump’s term begins.
content: Pope Francis on Monday named Cardinal Robert W. McElroy, bishop of San Diego, to be the next Roman Catholic archbishop of Washington, moving one of his most vocal allies on immigration to one of the most prominent posts in the American church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Hollywood’s Stars Were Out. Their Politics Were Not.
description: Sunday’s show was Hollywood’s first megaphone since Donald Trump was elected to a second term. This time, there was barely a peep about it.
content: Hollywood hoisted a white flag in the culture war on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Shaila Dewan
title: Minneapolis Promises Police Overhaul in Deal With Justice Department
description: With only two weeks left in the Biden administration, officials hurried to finalize a plan in the city where George Floyd was murdered.
content: The Minneapolis City Council unanimously voted on Monday to overhaul its police department to address a pattern of systemic abuses, as part of an agreement with the Department of Justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ariel Dorfman
title: The Regret That Haunted Me for 50 Years
description: I believed my friend died because of me. Fifty years later, I learned the truth.
content: This essay is part of How to Live With Regret, a series exploring the nature of regret and the role it plays in all our lives. Read more about the project here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David C. Adams and Frances Robles
title: Massacre Upon Massacre: Haiti’s Bleak Spiral Into a Failed State
description: In Haiti, gangs have killed hundreds of people and shot journalists at a news conference, exposing the country’s fragility and the government’s failures.
content: A fresh injection of about 150 foreign officers arrived in Haiti this weekend to bolster an international security force charged with taking on the powerful and well-armed gangs that have inflicted so much misery on the country for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Attia
title: 12 Easy Dinners That Start With a Can of Chickpeas
description: Because you probably already have a few in your pantry.
content: If you’ve ever found yourself standing in the canned food aisle, trying to remember if you have any chickpeas at home (you probably do), you’re not alone. Garbanzo beans are affordable, adaptable and can turn any weeknight meal into something substantial. Here are 12 recipes that will put them to good use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: What’s Trump Going to Do With All That Power?
description: What can we expect from the president-elect?
content: Bret Stephens: Happy New Year, Gail. Donald Trump will be president again in a couple of weeks. Is there any news on the horizon that gives you cause for optimism?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Los Angeles Braces for ‘Life-Threatening and Destructive’ Winds
description: Forecasters warned that a significant Santa Ana wind event this week could help wildfires spread quickly and erratically. Utility companies said they may pre-emptively cut off power to some customers.
content: With parched vegetation and one of the strongest Santa Ana wind events in years expected to sweep through Southern California this week, the region is bracing for the type of weather that can help wildfires spark and spread quickly and easily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: ‘The Brutalist’ Won Big at the Golden Globes. But How Can You See It?
description: Interested in watching the three-and-a-half-hour epic about a fictional Hungarian architect? Good luck if you don’t live in New York or Los Angeles.
content: “The Brutalist” won some of the top prizes at Sunday night’s Golden Globes, taking home the awards for best drama, best director and best actor in a drama. But it is exceptionally difficult for people to watch the story of the fictional Hungarian architect László Tóth, played by Adrien Brody, who tries to realize his grand vision in postwar America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: Giuliani Is Held in Contempt of Court in Defamation Case
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York City, has failed to turn over his assets to two Georgia poll workers who won a defamation lawsuit against him.
content: A federal judge on Monday held Rudolph W. Giuliani in contempt of court for failing to cooperate in the handover of $11 million of his personal assets to Georgia poll workers he falsely accused of helping to steal the 2020 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Stays in Florida During Election Certification
description: The president-elect spent the weekend at his golf club and estate, continuing to push the debunked idea that his loss in the 2020 election could have been legally overturned.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump was at Mar-a-Lago, his members-only club and home in Florida, nearly 1,000 miles away from the Capitol as a joint session of Congress certified his Electoral College victory on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Ian Austen and Ephrat Livni
title: A Timeline of Justin Trudeau’s Rise and Fall
description: The Canadian prime minister, who said on Monday he would step down, has spent a quarter-century in the political spotlight.
content: Justin Trudeau’s announcement that he would step down as Canada’s prime minister was expected after he faced political struggles in recent months, but it nonetheless represented a stunning fall for a leader once so beloved that his diplomatic meetings were marked by fans lining up to take selfies with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Scenes From the First Major Winter Storm of 2025
description: Snow mixed with sleet and freezing rain blanketed parts of the Midwest and Mid-Atlantic on Monday, leaving tens of thousands without power.
content: A day of momentous election certification and fraught memories in Washington, D.C., began on Monday with a quiet coating of snow blanketing the National Mall and softening the monuments. The snow fell thickly through the morning and was expected to continue into the night, bringing most activity around the Mid-Atlantic to a muffled halt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: National Day of Mourning for Jimmy Carter: What It Means, and What’s Closed
description: Jimmy Carter, the only centenarian ex-president, died on Dec. 29. Here’s what to expect on Thursday.
content: A national day of mourning will be observed on Thursday for Jimmy Carter, who died on Dec. 29 at 100 years old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Levine
title: Where to Find Great New York Slices in 2025? You Might Be Surprised.
description: Once confined to the five boroughs, the classic street snack has now gone fully nationwide.
content: Rexburg, Idaho, may be one of the more unexpected places to find a world-class slice of New York-style pizza. The windswept city, home to B.Y.U.-Idaho, is a three-hour drive from the nearest major airport and 2,200 miles from Manhattan. But from its electric oven, Righteous Slice is serving pizza that would not be out of place in Greenwich Village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Desiree Ibekwe
title: A Terrorism Resurgence
description: We explore the main reasons for ISIS’s resurgence.
content: The killing of 14 people on New Year’s Day in New Orleans was the latest sign of a resurgence in radical Islamist terrorism. Some of the attacks — like the one last week — seem to have been merely inspired by ISIS, the network of groups that are offshoots of Al Qaeda. In other cases, ISIS groups played an active role in the planning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Molly Parker Scrubs In for ‘Doc’
description: “I was only going to do indies for the rest of my life,” the actress said. Now she is the lead of a Fox medical procedural — and happier than ever.
content: The actress Molly Parker likes the moment when it all falls apart, when a character loses everything. “Because, do you just give up on life?” she said. “Do you just die? Or do you change?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn and Alice Callahan
title: Day 1: How Often Do You Buy Ultraprocessed Foods?
description: Today, you’ll go grocery shopping without leaving your seat.
content: When we started brainstorming the topic for our annual challenge, we reached a consensus pretty quickly that it should be about ultraprocessed foods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Genevieve Glatsky
title: Recognized by U.S. as Venezuela’s President-Elect, Edmundo González Meets With Biden
description: The meeting was part of Mr. González’s international tour to drum up support for Venezuela’s opposition.
content: He is widely believed to have won Venezuela’s presidential election, and by a landslide. But on Monday, instead of making preparations for his swearing-in at the palm-lined palace in Caracas, Edmundo González was at the White House meeting with President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Mel Shapiro, Director Whose Specialty Was John Guare, Dies at 89
description: He directed the playwright’s “The House of Blue Leaves,” and they helped turn “The Two Gentlemen of Verona” into a hit musical.
content: Mel Shapiro, an award-winning theater director whose collaborations with the playwright John Guare included their critically acclaimed musical version of Shakespeare’s comedy “The Two Gentlemen of Verona” and the Off Broadway premiere of “The House of Blue Leaves,” died on Dec. 23 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Names Nun to Head a Vatican Department, a First for a Woman
description: Sister Simona Brambilla was appointed as the prefect of a Vatican office that oversees religious orders, but she may not be alone at the top.
content: Pope Francis on Monday appointed Sister Simona Brambilla to head the Vatican office that oversees religious orders for both men and women — including more than a quarter of the world’s priests — making her the first woman to reach the No. 1 position in an office in the Holy See.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: The M.T.A. Is Counting on Congestion Pricing to Fix Mass Transit
description: The money raised from tolls will be used for essential repairs to New York City’s subways and buses. Without the upgrades, the system risks a meltdown.
content: Transit officials in New York City are counting on congestion pricing to generate billions of dollars to pay for urgent upgrades to the region’s subways and buses.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The ‘Darkest Day’: The Trauma of Jan. 6 Is Still With Us
description: Readers discuss a guest essay by a former Capitol Police officer and news articles. Also: Health coverage woes; investing in science education.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Bans New Oil and Gas Drilling Along Most U.S. Coasts
description: The ban affects the entire Eastern Seaboard, the Pacific Coast along California, Oregon and Washington, the eastern Gulf of Mexico and the Northern Bering Sea.
content: President Biden announced on Monday what he called a permanent stop to new oil and gas drilling across more than 625 million acres of U.S. coastal waters, saying he was making the move because drilling posed unnecessary risks to the environment, public health and the coastal communities’ economies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Wood González
title: Don’t Call It a Gym. It’s a Sporting Club.
description: Some fitness centers are trading in the minimalist industrial aesthetic for midcentury nostalgia and country-club preppiness.
content: When the five-star Gleneagles Hotel in Scotland set out to design a fitness center that would appeal to its next generation of guests, its designers didn’t look to the future. Instead, they turned to the past — specifically, a Slim Aarons photograph titled “Tennis in the Bahamas, 1957.” The result is the Gleneagles Sporting Club, a retro, luxurious sports facility with ample courts, equestrian stables and a courtside lounge space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Mobile-Home Lender Owned by Buffett Is Sued Over Risky Mortgages
description: A federal consumer bureau claims Vanderbilt Mortgage, owned by Berkshire Hathaway, made loans to buyers of manufactured homes it knew could not repay them.
content: A federal regulator sued a mortgage finance firm owned by Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway conglomerate on Monday, claiming it made loans to buyers of manufactured homes that it knew they could not afford.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Goodman
title: ‘Jerry Springer: Fights, Camera, Action,’ Plus 6 Things to Watch on TV This Week
description: Netflix releases a documentary on the 1990s talk-show host, and PBS airs “Finding Your Roots” and “Antiques Roadshow.”
content: Between streaming and cable, there is a seemingly endless variety of things to watch. Here is a selection of TV shows and specials that are available live or streaming this week, Jan. 6-12. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sinna Nasseri
title: Our Favorite Photos From the Golden Globes
description: Our photographer caught the stars as they arrived for Sunday night’s awards show.
content: The 82nd Golden Globes spread the love on Sunday night, handing out trophies to a range of films and TV shows led by the movie “Emilia Pérez,” which took home four. The stars spread the love, too, descending on the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Beverly Hills, Calif., for the awards ceremony, where the Los Angeles-based photographer Sinna Nasseri captured their candid moments as they arrived at the ballroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig and Soumya Karlamangla
title: Biden Visits New Orleans Monday to Mourn With Grieving Families
description: Mr. Biden’s trip to New Orleans, his latest as “consoler in chief,” joins a lengthy history of presidential visits to a city that has seen more than its share of tragedies and disasters.
content: In one of his final acts as “consoler in chief,” President Biden arrived in New Orleans on Monday to meet with the families of victims of the deadly terror attack that occurred on New Year’s Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah B. Solomon and Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Vice Chair Says He’s Leaving Role Early to Avoid Fight With Trump
description: Michael Barr oversaw an attempt to rewrite financial regulations that came under attack from a wide range of groups, including banks, lawmakers and even some of his colleagues.
content: Michael Barr will step down from his role as the Federal Reserve’s vice chair for supervision by Feb. 28, or sooner if President-elect Donald J. Trump appoints a successor, the Fed said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Inside the Golden Globes: What Comes After the Red Carpet
description: How Tilda Swinton, Kieran Culkin and other stars spent their night. (Hint: There was an all-you-can-eat sushi buffet.)
content: “Ariana Grande, Cynthia Erivo, Miley Cyrus, Selena Gomez, Angelina Jolie — oh my God, there’s been so many,” a young waiter standing at the front of the red carpet at the Beverly Hilton said on Sunday afternoon just after 4 p.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: How Austria Could Get Its First Far-Right Chancellor Since World War II
description: The leader of the anti-immigration, pro-Russia Freedom Party has been given the chance to try to form a government after months of coalition talks among mainstream parties collapsed.
content: The president of Austria on Monday gave Herbert Kickl, the outspoken leader of the Alpine country’s far-right Freedom Party, the task of trying to form a government coalition, three months after the party won the most votes in a general election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Lawyer Sues to Run for N.Y.C. Mayor on Independence Party Line
description: Jim Walden, who left the Democratic Party years ago, is challenging a law that bans the word “independence” on a ballot line.
content: A prominent lawyer who is a candidate for mayor of New York City filed a lawsuit on Monday seeking to run on the Independence Party line in the general election in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: The Jan. 6 riot, four years on.
content: Four years ago today, protesters stormed the U.S. Capitol with clubs, chemical irritants and other weapons, inflamed by Donald Trump’s lie that the 2020 election had been stolen from him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Elon Musk Hijacks U.K. Politics in Favor of the Far Right
description: With 211 million followers on social media, the multibillionaire seems intent on using his global platform to rattle British politics.
content: When Elon Musk asked his 211 million followers on X to vote on whether “America should liberate the people of Britain from their tyrannical government,” it seemed as if the post could only be tongue-in-cheek.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nazaneen Ghaffar and Jacey Fortin
title: Winter Storm Blankets the East Coast, With Arctic Air on Its Heels
description: Hazardous snow, sleet and freezing rain disrupted travel plans and caused power outages in the Mid-Atlantic region, as bitter cold set in.
content: A winter storm unfurled a blanket of snow and ice along the East Coast on Monday, disrupting routines in much of the Mid-Atlantic and the Northeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By River Akira Davis
title: Long Before Jeju Air Crash, South Korea Rose to Be a Model of Safety
description: After overcoming pariah status at the end of the last century, South Korea must learn what caused the catastrophe on Dec. 29 and what lessons to draw from it.
content: A Jeju Air crash in South Korea last week, the deadliest plane accident in years, has stunned the global aviation industry. The country is regarded as a model for how to turn poor air safety practices into some of the world’s best.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Goodman
title: Best and Worst Moments From the 2025 Golden Globes
description: From Nikki Glaser’s monologue and wins for “Emilia Pérez” and “The Brutalist,” it was downhill to all those pharmaceutical ads.
content: The bar wasn’t set very high for the Golden Globes on Sunday night. After last year’s host, Jo Koy, memorably bombed, the emcee this year, Nikki Glaser, could hardly do worse. But she wasn’t content to merely do better. After workshopping her opening monologue in dozens of club appearances over the holidays, she killed when it counted, cracking up the stars on hand at the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills, Calif., and winning over viewers on social media. The rest of the night went more or less smoothly, with a mix of expected and surprise winners. But it wouldn’t be an awards ceremony if there weren’t some truly off-kilter moments. Here are the highs and lows as we saw them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Saying Au Revoir to a Trudeau. For Now.
description: Canadians have soured on his brand of progressivism, but voters are fickle.
content: In politics, the pendulum never stops, and yesterday’s excitement becomes tomorrow’s handicap. Justin Trudeau should have known that: His father, Pierre Trudeau, bowed to public fatigue with his charisma and progressive policies in 1984 after 15 years as prime minister of Canada. Some of Justin’s colleagues had been urging him for some time to take a “walk in the snow,” a reference to what his father said he did before making his decision to step down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Al-Assad Is Out, but So Is a Revered Queen: Textbook Changes Unsettle Syrians
description: Syria’s new government has swiftly ordered changes to school curriculums. Some Syrians say the move is a worrying sign of how the former rebels plans to govern a diverse country.
content: References to the ousted President Bashar al-Assad and his father, who ruled Syria before him, have been removed, as have images of pre-Islamic gods. The definition of a martyr has been changed, and it now means someone who has died for God, not one’s country. A Roman-era queen has been taken out of some textbooks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar
title: How Will 2025 Be Different? Make a Prediction.
description: What do you think the new year has in store for us?
content: Does 2025 feel different to you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen, Vjosa Isai and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Here Are Four Possible Contenders to Succeed Justin Trudeau
description: Whoever replaces Mr. Trudeau as the leader of Canada’s Liberal Party will become the prime minister. Not long after they’ll face a general election, and the daunting challenge of keeping the job.
content: After 12 years leading the Liberal Party of Canada, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Monday said he was stepping down. His resignation sets off a succession battle in which some of the party’s most prominent faces will vie to replace him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Kieran Culkin Wins a Golden Globe for ‘A Real Pain’
description: Culkin earned his second Golden Globe in two years after being awarded for his role as Roman Roy in “Succession.”
content: Kieran Culkin earned his second Golden Globe on Sunday night, his first in a movie category, for his work in “A Real Pain.” In the film, which was written and directed by Jesse Eisenberg, who also co-stars, Culkin plays Benji, one of two cousins on a heritage tour of Poland to honor their recently deceased grandmother, who was a Holocaust survivor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1 Million Homes in California
description: A ranch in Forestville, a townhouse in Los Angeles and a Spanish-style house in La Quinta.
content: This single-story, two-bedroom, two-bathroom house is off a private road less than two miles from the Russian River. It’s within a five-minute drive of popular riverfront beaches with walking trails, boat launches and swimming areas. The center of Forestville, home to art galleries, wine tasting rooms and restaurants, is a 10-minute drive. Armstrong Redwoods State Natural Reserve, which has an amphitheater and a picnic area framed by towering redwoods, is 15 minutes away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Warns Americans Not to Forget the Jan. 6 Attack
description: In an essay in The Washington Post, President Biden accused President-elect Donald J. Trump and his supporters of trying to erase the history of that day.
content: President Biden warned Americans not to forget the violent attack that took place at the Capitol four years ago, and he accused President-elect Donald J. Trump and his supporters of trying “to rewrite — even erase — the history of that day.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess and Kate Christobek
title: Trump Seeks to Halt His Criminal Sentencing in New York
description: A Manhattan judge has already indicated that he will spare Donald J. Trump from jail time, but the president-elect is seeking to avoid the symbolic blow of the criminal proceeding.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s latest attempt to stave off his criminal sentencing in New York was denied on Monday, teeing up a frenzied series of last-minute appeals as his inauguration draws near.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Emily Anthes
title: First Bird Flu Death in U.S. Reported in Louisiana
description: The deceased was over 65 and had other medical conditions, state officials said.
content: A Louisiana patient who had been hospitalized with severe bird flu has died, the first such fatality in the United States, state health officials reported on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: centenary
description: This word has appeared in 45 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word centenary has appeared in 45 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 12 in “It Was Once Britain’s ‘Best’ New Building. Soon, It May Be Rubble” by Lynsey Chutel. She writes about the Centenary Building, completed in 1995. It was once the glass-and-concrete triumph of the University of Salford, outside the northern city of Manchester, but now the university deems the building obsolete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Nikki Glaser Kept Things Light (Mostly) at the Golden Globes
description: Taking on a hosting role with a strained past, the comedian won plaudits from critics and her comedy peers for her lightly bawdy jokes and Hollywood ribbing.
content: Nikki Glaser did not win a Golden Globe herself on Sunday night. “I’m first-time Golden Globe loser, Nikki Glaser,” she said after losing the award for best stand-up comedy performance to the comedian Ali Wong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: How America’s ‘Senior Citizens’ Became ‘Older People’
description: A new book traces shifts in the nation’s treatment of aging adults — for better and for worse.
content: “You see these gray hairs?” Dorothy Parker asked in The New Yorker in 1928. “Well, making whoopee with the intelligentsia was the way I earned them.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: A Reporter’s Reflection on Jan. 6, Then and Now
description: Luke Broadwater was at the Capitol when a pro-Trump mob stormed the complex on Jan. 6, 2021, as Congress was certifying Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory. Four years later, he reflects on what has changed.
content: A loudspeaker in the Senate press gallery crackled with a dire warning on the afternoon of Jan. 6, 2021, and a voice announced a lockdown as I sat at my desk in the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Durn
title: How to Start and Keep a Journal
description: Tips from writers, artists and a social worker that might make the practice less daunting.
content: It’s a familiar story: You buy a beautiful notebook, intent on starting a journal, only for it to sit untouched for years. While the benefits of journal-keeping are well established — it “can raise levels of optimism and life satisfaction,” says the psychology researcher Justine Richelle, 25, and strengthen creative writing skills (“The lines between what I write for myself and what I will ultimately write for publication are pretty blurred,” says the novelist Pico Iyer, 67) — that knowledge doesn’t necessarily make the blank page less intimidating. Here, a handful of longtime journal-keepers share advice that may inspire you to try again and stick with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. Steel and Nippon Sue Biden Over Decision to Block Merger
description: The companies argue in a lawsuit that the process of reviewing the transaction was corrupted by politics.
content: U.S. Steel and Japan’s Nippon Steel sued the United States government on Monday in a last-ditch attempt to revive their attempted merger after President Biden blocked it last week on the basis that the transaction posed a threat to national security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Nicolas Sarkozy Goes on Trial on Charges of Illegal Campaign Funding From Libya
description: The former French president has faced several legal cases since leaving office, but accusations that he received money for his 2007 election from Libyan authorities have been particularly damaging.
content: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy of France on Monday went on trial in Paris over accusations that his 2007 campaign received illegal financing from the Libyan government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Winter Storm Snarls Travel in Mid-Atlantic With Snow and Ice
description: The storm caused thousands of flights and dozens of train trips to be delayed or canceled. At Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington, all runways were closed Monday evening.
content: Snow, icy roads and frigid temperatures brought on by a storm moving through the Mid-Atlantic region on Monday disrupted a return to routine for millions of people after the two-week Christmas holiday period. In addition to closing offices and schools, the storm also interrupted travel across parts of the country with delayed and canceled trains and airplanes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen Murphy
title: How to Hit Peak Fitness After 40
description: You can’t train in middle age like you did in your 20s. But if you’re strategic, your best days can still be ahead.
content: Not long ago, 40 was considered over the hill in sports. But we are increasingly seeing athletes, like the skier Lindsey Vonn, 40, and the climber Chris Sharma, 43, staging midlife comebacks. Peak performance is still within reach for the rest of us, too. Just look at Ken Rideout, a father of four from Nashville who became serious about distance running in his mid-40s and then one of the world’s fastest marathoners his age by his early 50s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Where in the World Do These Popular Detectives Solve Crimes?
description: Try this short quiz on investigators and inspectors cracking their cases around the globe.
content: Try this short quiz on investigators and inspectors cracking their cases around the globe.
